content.description: Crux is at the bottom. Use two thin crimps and step up to gain another crimp and a side pull. Feet get better on the second half.
content.location: Directly behind hobbs problem on the opposite boulders.

content.description:
Sit-start on the slick sloper, with or without the left crimp.  Bust a tough first move up into the right-facing undercling and work your way up and left with good edges to the sloping lip.  Continue up and right along the lip to the top jug.

Stand-start avoiding the bad sloper, which is a couple grades easier and still good fun.
content.location: North face of the Leary/Bard Boulder

content.description: Climb the arete on the left/south face starting as low as you can.
content.location: Southeast arete of the Corner Boulder, adjacent to the Leary/Bard Arete

content.description: Climb the left side of the Leary Bard arete with some tricky footwork and big balls.
Sit start on the giant sloper and pull onto the wall. Make hard moves rightwards and traverse around the corner and finish up "Hobb's Problem V2".
content.location: Uphill side of the Corner Boulders. Same start as "Grit Dreams" and stay low.

content.description:
Most will find the crux is getting off the ground on this one.

Stand-start on the sloping dishes.  Make a couple tricky moves up to the left-hand sloper, then break right to the black knob and finish in the water pocket jug.
content.location: West face of the Leary/Bard Boulder, left side.  The face to the left of the Leary/Bard Arete.

content.description: Crux is the start. Use poor feet to gain better angle on the arete on more featured options for your feet.
content.location: Arete adjacent to hobbs problem. Other side of the arete to the 'unknown arete problem'.

content.description: Sit start with the right hand on a sloper and the left hand on a small crimp seam. Heel hook or do a hard lock-off to an undercling hueco. Match the hueco and make a big move out right to another hueco which is slightly better than the first. Continue up and right around the bulge on slopers until you can reach a decent hold on the lip and top out.
content.protection: 4 or 5 pads. There is a rock slab behind you. A spotter is always helpful.
content.location: From the Leary/ Bard Arete, this climb is on the opposite corner.

content.description: Work your way up the right side of the arete using thin sharp crimps and keen footwork.  Finish with a tricky and insecure slab top-out.
content.location: Right side of the southwest arete, Leary/Bard Boulder.
